text:
I am trying to formalize my understanding of mathematical completeness. Do you think the following definition I have been working on suffices:

_Completeness: an axiom system where each axiom is sufficient for deriving every true statement in that language._

elements.text: I am trying to formalize my understanding of mathematical completeness. Do you think the following definition I have been working on suffices:
Completeness: an axiom system where each axiom is sufficient for deriving every true statement in that language.

text: I would say an axiom system is complete if every  statement or its negation can be derived from the system's axioms. Maybe I misunderstand you, but the part "each axiom is sufficient" might be misleading, as it sounds like you mean you can pick a single axiom and derive any statement from it. I would avoid talking about true values, since that's a semantical aspect and derivability is syntactical.
